hints.content: Let's try each set of groups to see whether it equals $36$ pencils.

###$3$ groups of $6$ pencils

![3 groups of 6 pencils](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/7363b1edb8610a7e049322cb743245b6ea532ad2)

$6+6+6=18$ , so Owen **cannot** group his $36$ pencils this way.

###$9$ groups of $4$ pencils

![9 groups of 4 pencils](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/7f101af798320c330277af5f5ab258455377fc17)

$4+4+4+4+4+4+4+4+4=36$

So Owen can group his pencils this way.

###$6$ groups of $3$ pencils

![6 groups of 3 pencils](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/3dbc08fcfdd5413f466831585c84b092dfdb3965)

$3+3+3+3+3+3=18$ , so Owen **cannot** group his $36$ pencils this way.

###$4$ groups of $9$ pencils

![4 groups of 9 pencils](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/c5359bf543e9f1c4a9bd9395bcf23eb0dac0681c)

$9+9+9+9=36$ , so Owen can group his pencils this way.

Owen can groups his pencils these ways:

- $9$ groups of $4$ pencils
- $4$ groups of $9$ pencils

[[☃ explanation 1]]

question.content:
Owen has $36$ pencils.

**What are two ways Owen can group his pencils?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This would be $18$ pencils instead of $36$ pencils.
This would be $18$ pencils instead of $21$ pencils.
